history.content:
I have not taken 169 or 161, but have heard from friends who have taken 161 that it is a medium-ish level of workload and difficulty. Take that with a grain of salt. 

I am about to finish 162 over the summer, and as someone who did not do well in 61c (got a C), I would highly recommend against this plan. For 162, good understanding of 61c material is a must, and saves many hours of review. Knowledge of memory management is crucial, and practice with caching and paging is very important for a sizable portion of 162. I still use 61c discussion sheets and resources to keep up with material. That being said, there is review of 61c at the beginning of 162 and again when memory material comes up, but I dont think it will do anything unless you were comfortable with the material the first time you learned it. 162 is also incredibly high workload, coming from someone who is about average at C coding and debugging. Lots of information to take in, and lots of assignments to keep you busy. If you are early in your college career and not in a rush, then there are plenty of other courses you could take with 61c that would be better suited for your semester. I would like to note that all the courses you listed have been offered over the summer recently, so if you are planning ahead and have the time and inclination, you could schedule them over the next summer, should they (hopefully) be available again. 162 over the summer is insane. That being said, I am not the brightest student, but I was able to grind out and do well (so far) in 162 over the summer with a combination of dedication, and a bit of luck in meeting good groupmates and TAs. I wish you the best of luck!

I have not taken 169 or 161, but have heard from friends who have taken 161 that it is a medium-ish level of workload and difficulty. Take that with a grain of salt. 

I am about to finish 162 over the summer, and as someone who did not do well in 61c (got a C), I would recommend against this plan. I cant say how important 61c is for 161, but for 162, good understanding of 61c material saves many hours of review. Knowledge of memory management is crucial, and practice with caching and paging is very important for a sizable portion of 162. I am on track to get an A/A- in the course, but it was only after countless hours of review and practice of 162 and 61c material. I still use 61c discussion sheets and resources to keep up with memory management. That being said, there is review of 61c at the beginning of 162 and again when memory material comes up, but if you didnt do so well in 61c and dropped the course, I would really recommend finishing that course, or at least becoming really comfortable with C and the memory unit parts of 61c. 162 is also incredibly high workload, and this is coming from someone who is about average at C coding and debugging. Lots of information to take in, and lots of assignments to keep you busy. 61c is similar, but lower on the workload imo, but not by much. Take that as you will. If you are young, then there are plenty of other courses you could take with 61c that would be better suited for your semester. I would like to note that all the courses you listed have been offered over the summer recently, so if you are planning ahead and have the time and inclination, you could schedule them over the next summer, should they (hopefully) be available again. 162 over the summer is insane. That being said, I am not the brightest student, but I was able to grind out and do well (so far) in 162 over the summer with a combination of dedication, and a bit of luck in meeting good groupmates and TAs. I wish you the best of luck!

children.subject: Noted. Based on your response and that of many others, I don't even know what I was thinking.
Please do not take 61C and 162 concurrently. A good knowledge of 61C concepts is necessary right from the start in 162

I will not do it and thank you for your response. I'll try to take something like 170 + 61C/169A + 61C/186 + 61C depending on whether I can get off the waitlist for any of them for the Fall semester. I'll take 162 along with 168 in the spring.

First of all, as part of the staff of 61C this summer, I feel sorry that you couldn't do well. But hopefully we'll do better in following semesters. 

So back to the question, with the heavy workload of CS 162, I wouldn't recommend you taking it with another class formatted in a similar way, like CS 61C. From my personal experience, 162 is at least 2-3x as heavy as 61C. Also as Neil mentioned, it requires a lot of understanding of concepts about computer hardware and low level programming. Those are strictly related to what you learn in 61C.

My suggestion is, don't rush it, retake 61C whenever you feel ready, then take CS 162 in a following semester. Also if you're taking 162, try not to take more than 2 CS courses at the same time, even for a regular semester. And don't take it in summer. That hurts both your GPA and your mental health. Taking 61C with classes like CS 70 or 169 sounds good for me. Also, part of 161 is about C programming so you'll need the knowledge from 61C. After that you can consider taking CS 162, and other more advanced courses. If you want to take a break from the mess of 61C, that's also fine. Go ahead to take an algorithm class or maybe databases.
The student's response is very informative. Thank you for dissecting the CS162 workload for me. You, my friend, have shown me the light. Thank you!!

history.content:
Hello,

Are CS162, CS61C, and CS169A doable? Could replace CS169A with CS161 (whichever is easier to do). I was taking CS61C this summer but am dropping it since am not doing so hot in it so am very familiar with the material.

Planned schedule before change of plans was: CS162, CS161 and CS169A with a light breadth.
history.subject: Fall Schedule: CS162, CS61C, and CS169A/CS161
